body.p: By Christine Hauser

JERUSALEM, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Living up to his nickname, "The Bulldozer", Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon flattened Yasser Arafat's compound with army earthmovers and excavators -- monster-machines Palestinians hate as symbols of occupation.

In the past few days, the ungainly machines were at the frontlines of what Israel calls its war on terror. They went into high-profile action at Arafat's West Bank complex after Palestinian suicide bombers killed seven people in Israel.

The huge U.S.-made Caterpillar machines, outfitted with armoured modifications, bit into the stone walls of buildings in what became a wasteland, shearing off slabs of masonry. Rubble cascaded around their tracks.
On Monday, the army kept up its siege of the compound but the heavy machinery fell silent. Washington had questioned the demolitions, which Israel said were aimed at isolating Arafat.
"Israeli actions in and around the Muqata (headquarters) are not helpful in reducing terrorist violence or promoting Palestinian reforms," a White House spokeswoman said.

The ungainly machines had political reach in Ramallah, said an Israeli Maariv newspaper commentator on Monday, by smothering domestic pressure on Arafat for security and anti-corruption reforms. The siege had won him sympathy among Palestinians.
"The rebellion against Arafat which was gathering momentum over the past few weeks was suppressed and put down, at least temporarily, by Israel's bulldozers," wrote Ben Caspit.
HATED SYMBOL FOR PALESTINIANS

The burly Sharon earned his "bulldozer" nickname during a long military and political career, for ambitious army operations and for spearheading the planting of Jewish settlements on land Israel occupied in the 1967 Middle East war.
Since the Palestinian uprising began two years ago, the armoured bulldozer has been a key weapon in Israel's arsenal.
It has been used to demolish Palestinian houses, clear land for roads designated for Jewish settlers and destroy olive and fruit trees Israel says provide cover for gunmen.

"Israel has been using bulldozers since the beginning of the Intifada, usually in a razing policy," said Lior Yavne of the Israeli human rights group B'Tselem. "They are an important part of Israel's weaponry, just like a tank and an F-16."
They are key in implementing a new Israeli policy, criticised as collective punishment, to destroy houses of families of militants in hopes it would deter future attacks.
Army bulldozers shovel rubble and dirt to the entrances of Palestinian villages and cities to make them impassable to vehicles, in an attempt to stop militants.
"It became a symbol during this Intifada because it seems the Israeli policy is to destroy Palestinian infrastructure," said Palestinian human rights activist Bassam Eid.
"ZIONIST'S BEST FRIEND"
In the Israeli left-wing daily Ha'aretz on Friday, columnist Doron Rosenblum called the bulldozer "the Zionist's best friend".

"Not a day goes by" when the bulldozer is not featured in the headlines -- destroying a Palestinian militant's home, vineyards, expanding roads, and building and demolishing borders in Lebanon or villages and airfields in Sinai, he wrote.
"When did we become a nation for which the bulldozer is the symbol, the definer of its identity, the seal of its borderlessness, the pillar of dust that goes before the camp?
"Let it be recorded that from the seventh day of the (1967) Six-Day War down to our time, the intoxicating allure of the bulldozer has persisted unabated," Rosenblum wrote.
"Truly, is there a military, tactical, strategic, demographic, historiographic or even theological problem that cannot be resolved with the help of our metallic buddy?"
